What is it?Train Valley is a casual game where you must lay tracks to connect multiple stations to each other, and route trains without crashes or delays with the goal of sending trains to the correct station marked by a coloured flag.  It's not a tycoon or serious transport management sim and there is no cargo or passenger quota to manage.  It's more a strategy/puzzle type of game that challenges you to meet a set of goals before time or money run out.What's to like about it?It's silly in a fun way as the difficulty ramps up and you find yourself frantically clicking switches in the hope of avoiding crashes or wrongly-routed trains.  Some trains are faster and longer than others and it soon becomes manic.  Don't even think of trying a delaying tactic!  Keep a train waiting long enough and it will release itself whether you're ready or not!  The tutorial is somewhat scant but the game is intuitive to play with a simple interface.  You are not automatically thrown out of the game if you suffer a collision (luckily) though your profits take a hit and you'll probably need to do some track repairs.  You are given a set of objectives to meet for each location - of increasing difficulty with a greater number of stations to be served.What's not to like?Quite honestly, not much.  At first, it feels a bit TOO casual (ie Facebook style) but as the difficulty and number of stations ramp up, the game becomes a real challenge of strategy and timing.  The graphics are somewhat muddy and aliased (no in-game options to correct this).   Station colours can be a bit obscured by train flags at times when there are a lot of things going on, and a couple of colours are a little too similar which adds unnecessarily to the level of difficulty (for example: the orange and yellow station colours look very similar).  These are all minor gripes however, and don't detract from the fun of the game.In summary...Train Valley is no 'Sid Meier' or other type of management or tycoon sim, but it's a fun and addictive little game easily worth its low price.  Recommended!

												I don't play tower defence games anymore, because I have this game instead. If you don't see the appeal to tower defence at all, this game is not for you. If you've got the tower defence itch, this game will scratch it until it bleeds.This game doesn't have an undo button, so push your luck too far and it's game over. I know why that would put some people off, but it works for this game.Why is this better than tower defence? In any good tower defence game, getting good at it means learning how the towers work and how each enemy type works. Once you've figured that out, there's not much left to learn or do.With this game, the trains behave the same way (at different speeds) and the track laying rules are intuitive. Will you overpopulate your grid with trains to build up money, or will you play it safer with collissions, but risk facing bankruptcy? Can you time them perfectly so they almost hit but don't? What is the best configuration for the tracks? Is it worth paying extra to demolish your way through a shortcut? These dilemmas you get to face from game 1, without having to remember what does what.There is only one change I would make to this game if I were the developer, and that is this: When the game is paused, I want to still be able to see which trains are going full speed and which trains have only started moving. As a father, I love a game that I can pause and come back to after a nappy change, but I often forget which trains are going full speed and which are not by the time I return.

												Despite what you may think looking at the store page, this is more of a straight-up railroading puzzle game and less of a management sim, although it does a decent job of simulating a rail network. It's quite a good game too: fun, challenging and pretty to boot.However, I have to say that Train Valley reminds me of an older train puzzle game, one near and dear to my heart: 3D Ultra Lionel TrainTown[www.xtcabandonware.com], developed in 2000 by Dynamix. Whereas that game focused on completing missions and solving puzzles, in Train Valley your main goal is to simply survive until the end of a level without going bankrupt, although completing side goals earns you stamps of recognition. Train Valley has players reenact a more realistic depiction of railroading history - although it's mainly in the background - all the while attempting to stay afloat and expand to meet the needs of industry. Players take the role of a trainmaster, which means sending and routing trains to their intended destination.TrainTown has you manually hauling freight such as ore to smelters, hamburgers to grills, or numbers to multiplication equations. It plays its Lionel model train aesthetic to the hilt and is definitely "wackier", if you're into that sort of thing. Controlling multiple locomotives at the same time is only really needed in the later levels; although it's possible in every level, you'll usually only need to control one train at a time in the early game.In TrainTown, one crash fails a level, and some of those levels were as complex as any you may find in Train Valley. I mean, if the first set of levels was intended for elementary school kids, the last set was probably meant for college sophomores. I feel comfortable in saying TrainTown is harder, but oh so satisfying to play as well.I know this is a recommendation for Train Valley, which I absolutely recommend for puzzle and train fans, but if you like it I'd say you should give TrainTown a shot too. It's more or less abandonware at this point anyway, no harm in trying it.

Disclaimer: the key was provided to me for reviewingTrain Valley is a real time puzzle-strategy game based on trains and railroads. The player connects train stations and makes sure trains reach their correct destination by changing switches on the railroad he/she build himself/herself.The game has a nice simplistic menu that is shaped as a stockbook (book that is used by stamp collectors). Every Postage stamp in it is a level of the game. There are 20 levels total. The game has two game modes. One of them is classic mode which consist of levels that has a time and money limit, and also have optional objectives. The other mode is sandbox. As the name suggests, there are no restrictions and limits. Also in this mode, the player decides stations’ spawn time and when a train is scheduled from a station. At the beginning, all levels except the first one is locked. New levels are opened by beating the previous level. To play sandbox version of a level, the player needs to beat the same level in classic mode.First level is a tutorial level that shows basics of the game. Although it shows the most important parts of the game with nice message boxes, other parts are only mentioned in small bubbles that can be easily missed. Luckily, game is very simple and can be learned in a few games. That said, it would be nice to have a better tutorial.A level starts with two stations. Player is given some money to build railroads. After that trains start to be scheduled. When such train is scheduled, an icon appears on the station it is in. Then player starts the train by simply clicking it. That said, it is not possible to make a train wait forever. After an unknown time, it starts to count down from 5 and moves when the countdown reaches zero. As time passes, more stations are spawned making the game and railroad network more complicated. That said, it will never be too complicated as a tycoon but has its challenges of its own.Origin and destination of a train is handled very nicely in the game. It is color coded. Every train and station has a color on it. And the purpose is to make a train reach the station with the same color. When the train reaches its destination, the player gets the money. Amount of money is determined at the time of the spawn of a train. After that it will start decreasing even if the train is still in the starting station. This game is not a detailed tycoon game. It is designed as a puzzle-strategy game. The main purpose of the game in a level is not to bankrupt, but in this game, “bankrupt” means “negative money”. There are no loans, no maintenance cost, no economy. The player earns money by making a train reach its correct destination. After that he/she uses the money to build railroads to connect newly spawned stations. Every game year, a constant tax is debited from the money. There are only two ways the player’s money goes below zero; tax and train crash. As soon as the player’s money is negative, he/she loses. This mechanic is the games strategy part.The puzzle part is more interesting. Because the actual puzzle is built by the player without him/her realizing. After connecting a few stations with railroads, railroads become a (simple) maze with switches left and right. More stations mean more railroads with more switches. It is never possible to create a network without switches because of either landscape or money constraints. Towards the end of a level, the player keeps clicking switches to send the trains to correct road and prevent crashes. This is the most fun part of the game.Sounds in the game is nice and relaxing but it would be better to have a few different sound tracks.Total game length is a bit short. There are 20 levels but if the player doesn’t care about optional objectives, then they will end quickly.Pros:+ Simplistic: All menus and tabs are cleverly put together in a clear and simple manner.+ Relaxing: Because it is simple and lacks ambition, it is fit to be played just to relax.Cons:- Short: Don’t have many levels.Verdict:Train valley is a nice and relaxing game. It gives the feeling of playing actual toy trains and if you like trains, you probably will like this game. That said, because it is short, I recommend it to be best considered as a side game when you got bored of other stuff.P.S: As a rule, I won't comment on price tag. Everyone has a different opinion on whether it is worth the price tag or not. So it is up to you to decide.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator GroupEdit: Fixed some typos and formatting

												I've been looking for something to scratch the Transport / Railroad Tycoon itch for a while now, and although there are some potentially promising games on the horizon, it seemed like there were no good examples in the genre at the moment.And then I stumbled upon Train Valley, which, within a few minutes of playing confirms that the above is true - this isn't a tycoon game.  What it is, is a puzzle game - and once you get a few levels in, it's fiendish.  It conjurs up the correct mix of raising a smile when things go to plan, and swearing at your screen when you get overwhelmed and the inevitable happens - and trains crash.The premise is simple; you are given a grid and two coloured stations on each map, and you drag lines from one to the other, avoiding or bulldozing (at a cost) your way through buildings and trees, some of which are randomly placed whilst some are always in the same place.  Trains will spawn in the stations with a colour indicating that they want you to direct them to the other station, you click to launch the train and it makes its way down the track and you get paid when it arrives - each train has a value which ticks down from the moment it spawns to the moment it arrives at the destination.  The complexity comes in as the map progresses.  New stations will spawn on the map - in predetermined positions but in a random order, and begin to spawn trains all eager to go somewhere else.  You will lay more tracks, launch trains, and use the track switches to try and avoid a catastrophe.  Fortunately you can stop and reverse trains, but this doesn't always help if you're not keeping a good watch out - only one train can occupy a station, so it will launch itself if a second one is about to spawn.The difficultly ramps up; early maps serve to teach you the basics and later ones cram stations in awkward places with choke points to force trains onto the same pieces of track.  When things go well, it's great - but sometimes, you just can't avoid an explosion.Back to my search for a tycoon game - even though this clearly isn't one, the art style and simple way of laying track would lend itself very well to a more in depth strategy game which, if I were the developer, I'd seriously consider.

												Looking at Train Valley's (TV) store page a while back, I overlooked this game as a basic train simulator, when in fact it plays more of a puzzle game with some real-time strategy elements thrown in! TV uses some fairly simple but effective rules. Lay a track between stations, and deliver as many trains without incident, as quickly as possible. You can choose where to lay the track, purchased from the earnings you get from train deliveries, and trigger when the trains depart. These are colour coded to let you know where to send the train. You can also rush trains by purchasing them for bonus score & turn trains around or stop them.  Your money is always going down so the pressure is on!Where tracks overlap, you have get a switchboard, that you can reposition between your alternative track paths. On complex track layouts, this can be quite challenging to keep every train going where they should especially when you start to juggle multiple trains enroute at a single time. Good planning is a must!Puzzle mechanics are easy, but increase exponentially as paths multiply. As you progress through the 20 scenarios (+5 more in the DLC) across 4 seasons, the difficulty is increased by putting more obstacles in your way, increasing the frequency of the trains & also other level specific challenges. Each level has 3 bonus goals to achieve as well, which can be done on multiple playthroughs. When things get too hectic, you can pause the timer giving you a moment to regroup. Although the maps are small, there is ample variety in the challenges presented, they are thoughfully designed, balanced & do not become stale.Sound design is good, providing clear audio feedback to the actions occurring on screen, but these can get repetitive (especially the ding of the train leaving for me). Levels are clear to navigate and laying track is generally an easy task. Occasionally, you can lay a track as your mouse moves slightly to the adjacent square, causing issues laying things the wrong way. It would be good to be able to demolish for the same cost if the timer hasn't been resumed to recover costs (as income is limited).Likewise, the financial impact of two trains colliding plus the many squares of track loss often spells doom & essentially the end for your level. It seems a bit excessive at times, and can frustrate, as can that random train departure who has just got in the way of everything! Thankfully, most levels are pretty quick to balance this out to a degree.Despite these stress points, it has been hard to drag myself away from TV for very long. Still trying to beat some of the later levels in the German DLC. It is highly addictive once you get a few levels in and will continue to challenge your time management & coordination skills all the way to the last level.If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

												Train Valley is a surprisingly good title for not a whole lot of money. You just need to have the right expectations.This is no ecosim, it's a light puzzler with trains. Your goal is to connect the different train yards, of which more will pop up during any given scenario (always in the same place, but at possibly different times each time you retry the level, i.e. upper right instead of lower left and vice versa). Your only tool are tracks and demolition. This is complicated by the terrain and already present tiles with buildings, etc. on them, which makes construction a lot more expensive if you want/need to go through instead of around. After that it's "simply" a matter of sending out trains to the correct stations by manipulation of the railroad switches and avoiding crashes. Easier said than done sometimes.Trains will "spawn" after a set amount of time (indicated in the bottom right) and automatically leave the station if all stations have spawned trains already (i.e. you were either sleeping or you spawned extra trains and couldn't get them out in time). This can have dire consequences. The longer a train waits and travels the more of its monetary value it will lose. Since the game deducts a yearly fee (and the year goes by very quickly) you can end up bankrupt thus forfeiting the level completely, which means restarting from the very beginning, since there are no check points nor is manual saving a thing.Add to that 3 different bonus goals (fixed) for each level (spawn x additional trains, earn x amount of money, don't let a train go to the wrong station, don't press pause, etc.) and the game can become quite hectic, despite the availability of a pause feature. It is still easy to misjudge a train's speed though and send out the next too early, so they crash. The switches get out of hand in later levels, so mistakes are easily made, especially since any train going over a switch that does not have to be changed automatically aligns it as well, which can spell trouble for the following train if you're not on your guard.Crashes are pretty bad most of the time since they not only mean the train and money is lost forever, but you also have to rebuild the tracks, meaning even more money is lost. You could easily go bankrupt until the next train reaches its destination. However, you can stop a train and even turn it around at almost any given time, but of course this has other negative effects like loss of money and time.If you like a challenge or want to speed things up, you can do so by up to 4 times the regular speed (2x and 4x speed). Do not press the pause button and see if you can survive ;)The DLC "Germany" adds a new chapter to Europe, America, Russia and Japan, complete with new trains, new hazards and new music. Every region in the game features its own soundtrack and some levels have interesting hazards to play around with, for example unstoppable speed trains, or even bombing runs. Well worth it in my opinion.

												A perfect crossover between Pipe Dream and Flight Control HD.You layout rails to bring a constant flow of trains to their designated stations. Very easy concept but gets hectic as more stations spawn around the map and the train numbers increase.Each train you deliver will increase your money to build more tracks, and pay the taxes each year (which is very short in game time!). Trains lose worth fast, so don't deliver them fast and you risk going bankrupt.You can also launch extra trains at a random location for a fee. Gamble on this option to increase your cash, but abuse it and you'll end up overloading your network which is certain to lead to disaster, or to fun!Once you have multiple trains running between stations you'll need to micromanage switches and stop your trains if necessary (losing precious money) to avoid accidents which will always make your trains blow up violently; I think it must be explosives that you are delivering.You can play the levels in a variety of styles. Spend loads of cash to build a huge rail network which can support loads of trains running at the same time. Or play it stingy and try to see how many trains you manage to circulate back and forth on a single narrow piece of track. Both methods have their risks and rewards.Some of the later maps have special features, such as high speed trains that you cant control or stop, adding to the excitement.The campaign is not extremely long, but you have sandbox levels at the end of each stage, and stamp challenges on each level also increase replayability. This can make some easy levels very challenging, for example play the level without using pause, without stopping any train, and launch 10 additional trains.The game runs smooth and seamlesly performance wise, and hardly has any bugs. There are 4 (5 with DLC) countries which all have a pleasant and unique visual style, and the trains have some nice variety from around the world. You can see that the devs like their trains, even though this is a puzzle game, not a tycoon one.Also the game still receives attention from the devs, patches, and DLC. At the really honest price tag this is sold I can not do anything but recommend Train Valley to everyone!

												Train Valley has a simple premise. Bring Trains from one Station to another. But what the game makes out of this relatively simple premise is astonish. Why? Let me explain!GameplayIt all starts slow. Two Stations. One Train. The Interface is very intuitive and you will understand every function in absolutely no time. Of course the first mission is also a tutorial, so you will have no problem to get into the game mechanics. The game offers four chapters with six missions each. Also every mission has 3 “Expert goals” you can try to fulfill. These will change the way you play the mission, what is a motivation to play it again and reach them. But the final goal in every mission is the same. Get every Train that will spawn to their desired station without going bankrupt.Bankrupt? Yes! Every train as a certain value assigned. As longer as the train needs to reach its destination it loses value over time till it is at $0. After the first two missions the difficult raises pretty quickly, but the Missions are never getting unfair. You will have the motivation to try it again and never have the feeling that you lost because the mission design was unfair. ProgrammingI had no crash in my whole play time or any stutters. The game ran smooth at any given moment. Pros-Motivating Gameplay-Good tutorials-It’s very easy to get into the game-Motivating extra goals in each mission-Two game modes. Classic and FreeplayCons-Difficult raises pretty fast-The final mission goal is always the sameFinal thoughtsI found this game only because Steam suggested it to me, and I am really glad about it. Train Valley really took me by surprise. At any time I was motivated to beat the actuall mission and reach as many bonus goals as I could. And when I failed I could see why I did. The price it okay for what you get. Even if you just play through it without playing for the Expert Goals you will need some hours till you beat the final mission. Even if you never played such a game, like I did, I can still recommend this to you if the screenshots and the trailer appeal to you.

								   There is no casual train management strategy game quite like Train Valley.  Explore new worlds and learn the rail management skills to build, manage, and rule your great rail empire.  No train enthusiast on a budget can go without this game. There are a few kinks (i.e. buildings spawning on laid tracks and trains spontaeously exploding for no reason) but they are so rare or predicatable you can adapt to your situation.  I am proud to say I had the privelege to enjoy this game from early developement, and you can witness that experience for yourself in my let's play from the earliest alpha release to the most recent patch (a7.4/beta1.0 at this period) here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLq7fziG4I2WvsbCzGsxICVvHoK4CpOiuqI personally want to thank Flazm.com and Oroboro Games for the fantastic experience they provided me and cannot wait for the next patch.  There is so much more to experience!Advice for new users:-the bell, whistle or horn sound a locomotive makes leaving a station in this patch gives you a cue of how fast it will go regardless of what it looks like (mid or late 19th century steam, 20th century steam, early diesel, modern diesel)-the grid matrix in build mode is your friend; drag your cursor from a place that has track wherever you want, just be sure you are aware of how you drag your mouse cursor-dirt roads on game maps give you a hint about how to configure your tracks-compact triangular swicthing junctions are essential for saving money and space, crosing tracks are not-plot your track configuations while the game is paused to be safe (or don't for an extra challenge) :3-train crashes require track replacement at the point of impact (unless the impact point is in a station)-don't leave a train sitting in a station sitting for too long; it will eventually leave -consider in game annual taxes paid each new year before building or adding more trains (which both cost money)-trains going into the wrong station will go straight in and swing back out instantly, so be careful-avoid building over existing map strutures to save more money where reasonable-game logic prevents trains from derailling on switches regardless of which way they are oriented-building new tracks under existin tracks with trains still running on them will cause derailments (game logic won't save you here) -enjoy yourselfP.S. (Please don't throw rocks at me for sounding like a brown-noser, I just like this game a lot.)

												Train Valley is a nice game if you like trains and micro managing switches.Because this is 100% what this game is about.Also it has a demo, which is rare enough.The tutorial and the demo (which include the tuto + 2 levels) already shows you 100% of the gameplay.Bear in mind that all other levels are just "more of the same".So you goal is to build a railway (with switches all over the place) so that trains of a given color (there is a proper color-blind mode but all trains and stations have symbols, in addition to the color) reaches the stations of the matching color as fast as possible without bumping in other trains and without runing out of money.The longer it take a train to reach a station, the fewer money it earns you.Laying tracks cost money, with a penalty when you destroy something that already exist (house/tree).Each year passing by also cost you a maintenance fee.Each levels have three optionnal objectives, the real one is just no to run out of money.Completing the objectives by the end of the level (which have a predetermined duration) will earn you stamps.Even if it is easy not to run out of money, earning all the stamps is quite challenging. and will require you to restart some missions multiple times.The game has 24 missions, divided in 4 seasons which only slighly change the looks of the levels (they are themed Europe, USA, Russia and Japon).All levels are of the same size : super tiny, which is challenging and frustrating at the same time...I wish there were bigger levels.So feel free to test the demo, if you are not like "I want more of this" by the end of it, the game is not for you.Otherwise, it will occupy about 10+ hours of your time.If you are interested in some gameplay, I have a lest's play (in french) :https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLqtlWN_S1WDR-GXPgZvwNlmL71H-rinkD

												The very first thing you should know about this game is that it is not a business simulation! This is no Railroad Tycoon or Industry Giant. It is more of a micro management focused virtual model railway. If that sounds strange and unconventional to you you might want to check out the free demo first.The gameplay consists only marginally of financial management and largely of creating track layouts and manual train guidance. The challenge comes from creating connections between set stations and handling an ever growing amount of railway traffic that will put your planning skills to the test. With the help of 3 different game speeds and a pause button at your disposal you can decide yourself how reflex heavy each level will be.This game is best played in short bursts since each level can be finished within minutes. Yet it maintains a decently high level of replayability, especially for players that like to maximize their efficiency and want to perfect track layouts for optimal capacity.The level design is appealing and varied with an almost toy-like aesthetic. And the music is appropriately soothing and up-beat. Though it might get repetetive if you decide to 'binge' the game and finish it in one sitting.Depending on your personal aim in terms of perfection and Highscores that may take you between 5 and 20 hours.Overall you can expect a very pleasent experience for a rather low price tag.

Someone also compared it to "Lionel's(?) Train Town" which is also a fair comparison to make!To start with, it's not a tycoon game so don't be fooled by the images if they look like a Railroad Tycoon. The game is more focused on being a puzzle game based around trains. I'm sure if you've played Railroad Tycoon or the like you've had to overcome complicated junctions or network improvements the puzzles tend to focus on that skill - placing stations in awkward places. Every so often the game will general a train which will be at one of the stations (there's a gauge timer thing at the bottom right of the screen so you can see when the next train will generate) - you can also call on addional trains to create additional revenue. The train will be assigned a colour and you have to create a route via the switches/junctions you've made in your solution to get the train to it's destination. Laying track and destroying objects costs money and, along with a tax you have to pay, your balance can deplete quickly - going below 0 results in bankrupcy and you lose the game.There are four different regions progressing in difficulty. Difficulty in this game is present through awkwardly placed stations, objects to either neogotiate around or destroy and build over at an addition cost (depends on what you destroy for cost) and the challenges present in each level (spend x money, don't let trains go to the wrong stations, etc) create some replayability.This is a fun puzzler and the trains were just a bonus (well, at least for me anyway).

								I bought this game because I enjoy building train layouts, liked the original Railroad Tycoon way back in the early 90s, and like optimization puzzles.  That's good, because this game hits all those likes of mine to some degree, and I love it for that.What you do:  you build tracks between stations, and dispatch trains that the game randomly builds (or, you can summon your own in addition to the random ones).  Each scenario is a bit different--goals for specific scenarios don't vary within the scenario, but placement of stations and obstacles do to a degree.  In general, goals are of the variety:  don't crash trains, build X amount of track, make X amount of money, manually summon X amount of trains.  These sound simple, but the land area of each scenario is small and you need to make efficient rail networks in that small space without going bankrupt. Additional stations appear as the game progresses, so you have to modify your rail network on the fly.  This isn't a surprise after your first scenario, but they are also placed somewhat randomly in a random order, meaning you have to think on the fly.  Thankfully, the game does include a pause button and you should make use of it often.  You direct the trains as you go, throwing switches to put trains on specific paths.  Screw up switching even once, and you may be restarting the scenario if it's a bad enough miss.  :)Good:  engaging play, certainly not a piece of cake, but not impossible either.  Graphics are clean and perfect for this kind of game.  Music and sounds work well and fit the game.  Bugs are pretty much non-existent.  Meh:  keyboard shortcuts appear to be unlabeled nor identified, and not changeable.  Some of them can wreak havoc with your game.  No ability to save in mid level, and scenarios aren't super quick.Bad:  Scenarios often have razor thing win margins.  This is not unusual for optimization puzzle games, but can be frustrating if you've never played one before.  So, perhaps this isn't a "bad" thing, as I'd sure not want this changed.  Still, it comes as a warning--not so much to stay away from the game, but don't give up on it too quickly.Overall:  Highly recommended for those who like optimizing things for fun, designing rail networks in confined spaces, and choo choo trains.  Easily frustrated by puzzles?  Probably not for you.

												This is a fun little train game.  It's economics are exceedingly simple as is the user interface.  The basic game play is simple.  Lay track, control swiches, send trains to the right stations, don't run trains into each other or off the track.The challenges, however, can be very difficult.  You may be required to earn a specific minimum amount of money while getting all your dispatches perfect, and doing so will require you to schedule extra trains that you can only just barely get enough routed, while trying to make sure you're switches are all lined up so the trains don't run into each other and end up on the right track.Some reviewers have said the game is short.  This is true- there are only 24 scenarios and no scenario takes more than an hour.  However, the harder scenarios have great replay value and frankly will take many attempts to master anyway.For enthusiasts of games like Railroad Tycoon (and I am a HUGE fan myself), this takes train management down several notches to the level of operating your own home layout - which quite frankly is something I've no doubt many people have been longing for because for all the wonderfullness of Railroad Tycoon, what it is NOT is a train dispatcher simulation.  Train Valley is.Pros:- Simple interface, simple economics- You run trains, not companies- Scenario complexity is just the right level of hard- Feels like a home train layout vs. a national railroad modelCons:- UI needs refinement- A little cutesy looking- Feels like a home train layout vs. a national railroad model (yes this could be a pro OR con)Overall?  4 stars with potential.

												Train Valley met my expectations.  I find the videos and screenshots to be misleading, as they feature zoomed in views of the map.  I play zoomed all the way out so I can always see the entire map.  I don't see any advantage to zooming in.  Each level starts with two or three stations.  You decide where the track goes.  Trains appear at random stations, and you need guide each train to its desired destination.  As the level progresses, more stations appear.  You have much more control than in Mini Metro, and consequently you do more micromanagement - mostly toggling switches to try to route trains where you want them to go.  On the plus side, this means that when things go wrong, it is almost always your fault, whereas success in Mini Metro depends more on luck and chance.  More trains + more track + more switches = more complexity.  You can also call in extra trains for extra points.  The challenge is designing and discovering track layouts that are easy to manage.  Some of the UI elements could be improved (see my comment in the Steam discussions), but I have adapted to the unfortunate UI deficiencies.

												Train Valley might look like a 'casual' game, but it's far from easy, and approaching it as a loose, casual game will only bring you grief! You need to make friends with the 3-step speed controls and the Pause button in order to succeed. That's because although laying your track is half the battle, the funds to build and destroy it come from the deliveries you make, and crashes and wrong destinations all impact your income. In other words, the main fight here is with scheduling your trains. The game mechanics are fairly intuitive, and of course the more you play, the more you understand. In this way, Train Valley is both rewarding and frustrating, because there are still some things that require some time and attention to understand. One key concept here, which I'm still not entirely sure about really, is of your trains taking off of their own accord once the cargo value timer has dropped to a certain point. This appears as a set of tiny figures above each train, and if I have only one complaint with the game, it's that this essential bit of information is too small to see comfortably. There is a handy option to scale the UI up and down, although the figures don't scale with it.The feedback between your tack layouts and the efficiency of your scheduling is pretty tight -- get one right, and the other will work so much the better too. With successive timely deliveries made, your cash reserves will be able to cope with the odd crash or mis-direction. In the end though, it's easy to over-spend, so walking that tightrope between track design and scheduling is, again, crucial.As much as Train valley is about quickly clicking on your junctions and switches, the game definitely gives your brain a good workout, in much the same way that Bridge Constructor-type games do. I think it's well worth the 10 Euro Steam price, although I got mine for 2 Euros from Bundlestars, which is an absolute steal, frankly. Great game, and I highly recommend it.

												Before I get into the review here's the basics of how the review will work. There are normally 10 categoriesthat I use when reviewing a game. Those ten categories are Fun, Creativity, Challenge, Graphics, Music, Cinematics, Story, Content, Controls, Gameplay. Each Category will be rated 1 through 10 with a maximum score out of 100.So let's get started on the review.Train Valley is an Indie, Simulation, Strategy game published by Flazm and developed by  Alexey Davydov, Sergey Dvoynikov, and Timofey Shargorodskiy, and was released on September 16th of 2015. Category 1: FUN (10 out of 10).After playing about 40 minutes of the game I have found that the game is actually quite entertaining to me. While I'm not normally a puzzle gamer this game did catch my eye as I do have quite an interest in trains in general.Category 2: Creativity (10 out of 10).In this Category my perspective is that mostly for train based games, I've normally found simulation or strategy types without a puzzle element. Now while I'm sure that there are other puzzle genre train games out there, this is the only one that I have come across in these early days of my gaming channel. I'm sure that I'll be finding more out there.Category 3: Challenge (10 out of 10).In the beginning of the game, as to be expected, there was no challenge at all. At first I thought the challenge aspect wasn't going to really build up but by the fourth level, I found that I was just lying to myself. Things got quite interesting in fact. Now, I only made it the first 5 levels before I started becoming flustered and gave up.Category 4: Graphics (10 out of 10).The Graphics in this game seem to me to be a bit child-like cartoonish, but in all honesty I also feel that being a family friendly game, it was meant to be done in this fashion. My framerates while both generally playing and recording this video stayed steady between 29 and 30 frames per second for me while utilizing an MSI R7 250 2gb pci-e video card with the resolution set at 1920 by 1080, with the fullscreen option ticked and quality settings put at recommended (which I believe were at the highest quality settings.) It was easy enough to see everything with my vision problems and the textures were quite decent for the style given.Category 5: Audio (06 out of 10).There's really not much to be said about the music in the game other than it seems to be one looped track throughout what I've played. If the music changes in the game, I've not been made aware of it as of yet. That being said, the music seems to be slightly upbeat and wasn't overtaxing on my ears; however, I do tire of the same thing on a constant basis when it comes to instrumental music. I'd prefer variety and would have liked to seen more tracks during my gameplay. The sounds effects however were lovely and I was able to distinguish what I was listening to based on the effects of the actions taken. The sound effects is basically what is saved this category.Category 6: Cinematics (05 out of 10).The only cinematics that I've experienced is at the beginning of the game and between the levels where the portfolio book opens and the levels get stamped. Now, while a lot of others would not call it cinematics but more along the lines of animations which would end up in graphics, I felt as if putting it here would be the best choice. That being said, I felt as if they could've used a bit of work by actually making the animations into a more lively cinematic by adding an arm coming from the screen and a hand actually opening the portfolio. I would have also like to have seen some sort of cutscenes either animted or filmed to help fit the story line. Category 7: Story (08 out of 10).While there is a Story Mode to the game I've not really witnessed the story, but based on several reviews I've read including those from Steam Users and well known reviewers the Story is pretty good. I didn't have the time to fully delve into the Story itself, I've rated this Category based on many many reviews both positve and negative. Category 8: Content (08 out of 10).With 15 different trains and 18 different cars I was quite happy in the beginning with what was available. While I didn't get to witness all of the trains or cars personally during my short playtime, I was quite happy with the levels 'release' of train types based on level and time and am quite positive that as the Story unfolds any player will love experiencing each type. I would also love to see future releases of content with more cars and engines and maybe even some sort of expansion pack or update that allows more freedom. I would even like to see turntables and signals added into the game to give a bit more realism in stopping or turning the train around. Maybe even an option to also choose an engine type when selecting an early train. But all in all, I'm satisfied with what is available now. Category 9: Controls (10 out of 10).First let me just say that I love the controls in this game; and one of the things I like most is that you can map the controls to your liking. Control mappings are Switch mode, Build mode, Demolish mode, Scheduling additional trains, Pausing, Speed settings and even the Menu. You also have the capability of inverting the zoom functionality as well as adjusting the scroll speeds to your liking. The mouse movements were very fluid and I was able to hit switches with ease as well as getting the trains to stop and reverse with great ease. With all the games I've played, I never could stand having to put the mouse in a very small precise locations in order to toggle something and that includes train as well as aviation simulators. I was quite pleased with how well the controls were made. Category 10: Gameplay (10 out of 10).The gameplay itself was quite easy to understand from the beginning and the small video tutorials that popped up were a huge help. For being some one who's easily distracted, I was able to keep focues while playing lest I wreck everything and destroy the world. I also loved the fact that if you didn't acknowledge a train within a certain timeframe that they would depart anyhow, and if you aren't paying a lick of attention, there's no telling where that train could end up. As the cities grew I was fascinated by each building popping up as trains arrived, as if the city was growing. As the game continues and I progressed the levels I became more and more interested in the game.Overall Rating: So when all is said and done, I'm giving Train Valley an overall rating of 87 out of 100. I was quite pleased with everything and looking forward to playing this game a lot in the future as a wonderful way to either pass time or test my logic when I'm feeling quite... illogical. Thanks for reading my review and I hope it helped in your decision regarding the purchase of this game. Early Access Review
								Very enjoyable railroad building game, with attentive developers willing to listen to the players on possible improvements.The latest update helped to alleviate the bankruptcy issue, leaving the challenges of actually running the trains and building the tracks the focal point.  Beware! Some trains schedule themselves for departure, and you have to be ready to  handle them, or suffer the consequences.The overarching victory condition on all levels is to survive. The bullets shown on the right of the screen are optional, and none of them need to be achieved in order to advance to the next level. Those optional bullets are very challenging, and add replayability to the game.The actual laying of the tracks and placing of the switches is very easy. Faster trains become available as you progress through the level you are playing, but watch out for older, slower trains as they are NOT retired, but continue to function, adding additional challenge to the level.The graphics are nice and functional. Same for the trains.This is one of those games where you'll want to play until you beat the current level, and can't wait to conquer the next.Definitely worth the price of admission.

												Love the idea, hate the execution.It has a really weird loose condition: you can't have negative balance, like in all other economy based games, resulting in regular and spontaneous "You are bankrupt" pop ups, while you have 4 really expensive trains on there way to the stations. I have a 27' monitor and it's hard to spot most essential gameplay information when you need to. The tools icons are like 20 pixels at the top of the screen and the new train icon on the station (most essential gameplay ui element in the game) is like 5.Track building tools are rather unresponsive, far from polished.The lack of a proper tutorial is a pain also.It's sad, that developers didn't put enough effort here. 												Train Valley is a fun casual puzzle game. The screenshots and Steam tags may give you the impression that it's a management sim/tycoon game, but this is not really the case.The core gameplay is fun enough. You build tracks to connect the various stations and then try to get each train to the right destination by manipulating the railroad switches. During each level new stations will keep popping up, forcing you to expand your rail network.Your main goal in each level is simply to avoid going bankrupt (this is pretty easy for the most part). Additionally, each level has three bonus objectives that provide extra challenges. Some levels also have special trains arriving from outside the map. All in all there's enough variety to keep things interesting for a single playthrough.My main issue with the game is the fairly high level of randomness. For the most part this is not really a problem as the game is pretty easy anyway, but in the later levels bad luck can really mess you up. This is not really something I enjoy in a puzzle game.Overall I found Train Valley a pretty enjoyable experience. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes light puzzle games.The good:- Fun puzzle gameplay- Rather relaxing experienceThe bad:- Too many random elements- Building tracks is somewhat imprecise- Some of the later levels get rather micromanagement heavy
